subject: RE: [junit] setUp versus constructors

messageBody:
In JUnit 3.8.x and earlier, the test cases were used for several purposes:
specifying what was to be run, running the tests, and reporting results. The
test case instances would be constructed at some time before the test was
run. Consider a test which allocated a limited external resource. If I
created more than one test case of a given class, there would potentially be
a conflict. SetUp(), on the other hand, is guaranteed to be run just before
the test method, so it is safe to allocated external resources in setUp().
With JUnit 4, the test case instances are guaranteed to be created one at a
time, as they are run, so this argument no longer holds.

A second argument for setUp() is symmetry. Allocating resources in setUp()
and de-allocating them in tearDown() is nicely symmetric, whereas allocating
them in a constructor and de-allocating them in tearDown() is not. If you
don't have to de-allocate any resources, then this argument no longer holds.


I'll be experimenting with initializing test cases in field declarations and
constructors to see if I like them better that way. In general, I am a fan
of expressing code a declaratively as possible, which argues in this
direction.

Cheers,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Subject: [junit] setUp versus constructors



I've been using JUnit for a few years now, and one thing that's always
bothered me is the "setUp" method.

I always do my initialization in my constructor (if I'm not just doing
it at the field definition) as constructors allow me to initialize
final fields. The semantics of using a constructor also seem far more
obvious to me as everyone reading my code knows Java, while not
everyone is a JUnit guru.

The additional complexity of having the (as far as I can tell)
redundant setUp method seems counterproductive, so why does setUp exist?
